title: 108_hr4661
content: The Act titled "Internet Spyware (I-SPY) Prevention Act of 2004" addresses penalties for unauthorized activities related to computers. The "Internet Spyware (I-SPY) Prevention Act of 2004" introduces a new section, Sec. 1030A, under Chapter 47 of title 18, United States Code. It penalizes the illicit indirect use of protected computers, including unauthorized access or exceeding authorized access to a computer to use a program or code for furthering a federal criminal offense. Penalties include fines or imprisonment up to 5 years. The "Internet Spyware (I-SPY) Prevention Act of 2004" introduces a new section, Sec. 1030A, under Chapter 47 of title 18, United States Code. It penalizes the illicit use of protected computers, including unauthorized access or exceeding authorized access. Violators may face fines or imprisonment up to 2 years. No civil action can be brought under state law based on violations of this section. The terms "protected computer" and "exceeds authorized access" are defined, and "personal information" includes a first and last name. The new section, Sec. 1030A, under Chapter 47 of title 18, United States Code, prohibits the unauthorized use of personal information, including names, addresses, email, phone numbers, SSN, and financial information. Law enforcement activities are exempt from this section. The new section, Sec. 1030A, in Chapter 47 of title 18, United States Code, prohibits unauthorized use of personal information. Law enforcement activities are exempt. SEC. 3. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2005 through 2008, $10,000,000 allocated to the Attorney General for prosecuting spyware and phishing. SEC. 4. Findings and sense of Congress on enforcing cybercrimes. Congress finds that software and electronic communications are increasingly used by criminals to invade computers without authorization, particularly through spyware and phishing scams to obtain personal information for theft. These activities not only cause devastating damage but also undermine citizens' confidence in using the Internet. Given the rise in cybercrimes using software and electronic communications, Congress believes the Department of Justice should vigorously prosecute offenders using all available tools. The House of Representatives passed a bill on October 7, 2004, targeting cybercriminals who use spyware and conduct phishing scams.
